column1: It's very top heavy and super super thin at the Center position. Last year's draft class probably had better depth of talent. Though i do think some very good guard prospects are being severely underrated (Jared Butler/Miles McBride/Davion Mitchell)

>maybe one outside of the top 5  Bouknight for sure is one. I actually think I might have him a touch too high here. If UConn flames out hard, I could see if slipping because the SG market is ridiculous competitive for this draft. His whole schtick is that hes been one of the best scorers in college basketball and if that slips, then so does his stock.  He's a bit on the older side (relative to the one and dones) and his entire impact is in his scoring.  If he shows he can't get it done in the tournament, I could see him slipping hard, but if he does, I think theres a reasonable chance that a GM could bite on him on the first guard outside of Cade/Green/Suggs. Though I personally think he's a bit of a fools gold - that'll just show through unless he can have a great tournament.  Ayo Dosunmu is another. Ayo has a lot of question marks in terms of his NBA role and ability for things to translate, as well as his age curve, so if he can keep himself in the spotlight and continue to prove that hes simply better than the competition as an elite scoring option, I think that would be hugely beneficial. I could see a team reaching on him hard if he leads teh Illini far, but also dropping if he's forgotten about quickly after an upset.  >another currently out of your 1st round  Herb Jones just played the best basketball of his career leading Alabama to the SEC championship and I think Alabama are a decent darkhorse in the tournament. I personally believe they should have been the 1 seed over Michigan. He will have a ton of eyes on him  if he leads Alabama far, and theres plenty of contenders with late 1sts who could use his role player skillset.   Miles McBride is another (for 3rd seed WVU), but I technically included him in the 1st for this mock (for the first time), but im really not confident at all he will be a 1st rounder.

>there are usually more than 4 solid three point shooters in the lottery lol.  Well, there are 5 this year. Let's check the past few drafts.   2020: Toppin(low volume), Smith(low volume), Vassell, Haliburton, Lewis, Nesmith.  2019: Morant, Hunter(low volume), Garland, Johnson, Washington(low volume)  2018: Young, JJJ(low volume), Bagley(low volume), WCJ(low volume), SGA(low volume), Mikal Bridges, Miles Bridges, Robinson  There are usually about 3-4 actual proven shooters in the lottery of each class, not counting guys with solid percentages that only have like 2 attempts per game.   ------------  >and no chance in hell those guys guard 3 positions at an average level.  Name which one of them couldn't guard 3 or more(not counting McBride who I already said).

When Miles McBride was asked who was his toughest cover between Cunningham, Mitchell and Reaves, he said Mitchell without a doubt.  Then theres the whole defensive player of the year thing on the other side of the ball.  And the fact that Baylor reached heights its never been before might have something to do with it.  Idk, lol.

Nerlens Noel, Mitchell Robinson are top defenders at their position. Reggie Bullock was a solid defender last year, Elfrid payton (despite being garbage) is a decent defender, RJ is coming to his own on defense. Miles McBride looks like he has the tools to be a great defender.
We got Miles McBride and Jericho Sims this year with 2nd round picks. Just sayin'

Josh Christopher, James Bouknight, Jalen Johnson, Ziaire Williams, Evan Mobley  My thinking was to start with the best player from 21-60, since it's the hardest place to find talent. Then go with Mobley since he's the highest value C and it's the hardest position to fill using this draft. From there, you slot in the BPA for each segment.   For 21-60, I went with Josh Christopher, but I could be sold on Cam Thomas or Miles McBride, maybe even Sharife Cooper. Just the highest ceiling guard in that range (deepest position overall).
Alperen Sengun, Jalen Johnson, Quentin Grimes, Cam Thomas and Miles McBride were the 5 who I felt dropped too far.

The "maybe" isn't saying we might not have to offer them, it's saying that those players might be untouchable in the Knicks FO's eyes  Even without those players you're getting Noel/Burks (both moveable contracts who would certainly be traded for more assets for the Blazers), Obi Toppin, Miles McBride, Jericho Sims, Quinton Grimes, Mitchell Robinson (5 young players), and a LOT of picks. You can decide for yourself if the Blazers would take that (I wouldn't) but it isn't the most ridiculous package ever considering what Harden went for.  I would be shocked if we get Dame without moving one or both of RJ/IQ

some combo of:  Nerlens Noel, Alec Burks, RJ Barrett (maybe), Immanuel Quickley (maybe), Obi Toppin, Mitchell Robinson, any of our future picks, Miles McBride, Quinton Grimes, Jericho Sims  I don't think it beats the Sixers package if they offer Simmons + another player + picks

The problem with IQ is he doesn't really run an offense. He does his own thing which is either dump the ball off or create for himself, which is great when he's hot but when he's not then his teammates are going to suffer for it. 20 minutes a game is just right for him IMO, I think Miles McBride will also be deserving of some minutes too
